user.speaker: user
user.text: do you think indian people working in agriculture industry make money

agent.speaker: agent
agent.text: Labourers do not get more than Rs. 80 in the private agricultural labour market. On an inflation adjusted 1973 Rupee basis, the average income of Indian agrarian labourer was Rs. 7.20 per year in 1885.

contexts.text:
National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, 2005
The workers points of view can be summed up as : labourers do not get more than Rs. 80 in the private agricultural labour market , there is no farm work for several months ; few old age people who are jobless for at least 8 months a year ; when farm work is available they go there first ; farmers employ only young and strong persons to work in their farms and reject the others and hence many go jobless most of the time .
contexts.title: National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, 2005

contexts.text:
Poverty in India
These colonial policies moved unemployed artisans into farming , and transformed India as a region increasingly abundant in land , unskilled labour and low productivity , and scarce in skilled labour , capital and knowledge . On an inflation adjusted 1973 Rupee basis , the average income of Indian agrarian labourer was Rs. 7.20 per year in 1885 , against an inflation adjusted poverty line of Rs. 23.90 per year . Thus , not only was the average income below poverty line , the intensity of poverty was severe . The intensity of poverty increased from 1885 to 1921 , then began a reversal . However , the absolute poverty rates continued to be very high through the 1930s . The colonial policies on taxation and its recognition of land ownership claims of zamindars and mansabdars , or Mughal era nobility , made a minority of families wealthy , while it weakened the ability of poorer peasants to command land and credit . The resulting rising landlessness and stagnant real wages intensified poverty .
contexts.title: Poverty in India

agent.original_text: Based on the information provided in the document about poverty in India, it can be inferred that the income of Indian agrarian laborers was low in the past. In 1885, the average income of an Indian agrarian laborer was Rs. 7.20 per year, which was significantly below the poverty line of Rs. 23.90 per year. However, the document does not provide information on the current income levels of Indian agricultural workers. Therefore, it is not possible to directly answer your question without additional information. However, it is worth noting that agriculture is a significant source of employment in India, accounting for a large portion of the country's workforce.
